title: Boolean AND is Commutative
description:
Prove that boolean AND (`andb`) is commutative: the order of arguments does not matter.

**Goal:** `forall a b : bool, andb a b = andb b a`

Since `bool` is a finite type with two values, you can prove this by exhaustive case analysis on both arguments.
hints: Use `destruct a` to case-split on the first boolean
Then use `destruct b` to case-split on the second boolean
Each of the four cases should simplify to a reflexivity proof
prelude: (* No imports needed â€” bool, andb are in Coq's prelude *)
template:
Theorem andb_comm : forall a b : bool, andb a b = andb b a.
Proof.
  (* Your proof here *)
Admitted.
solution:
Theorem andb_comm : forall a b : bool, andb a b = andb b a.
Proof.
  intros a b.
  destruct a; destruct b; reflexivity.
Qed.
